subject: Sleep
title: Teen Brain Pruning and Sleep
description: Learn Teen Brain Pruning and Sleep in one minute.

hook.text: The teenage brain destroys up to one percent of its synapses per year. This destruction is progress.

buildup.text: Adolescence triggers massive synaptic pruning, eliminating weak connections to refine brain networks.

discovery.text: Much of this pruning happens during sleep, guided by which connections were used during the day.

twist.text: Sleep-deprived teens may prune less efficiently, potentially affecting the development of adult brain function.

climax.text: The prefrontal cortex, the last region to mature, is especially dependent on sleep for proper pruning.

punchline.text: Teen sleep builds the adult brain through selective demolition.

quiz.question: Why is sleep important for the teenage brain?
options: It guides synaptic pruning that refines adult brain networks
It stops brain development until adulthood
